Introduction
Assistant Director, National Identification Service, USDA-APHIS. I supervise the national entomological taxonomists, who are responsible for providing authoritative identifications of insects intercepted on cargo and goods at U.S. ports of entry. My background is as a molecular systematist of butterflies, with an interest in theory of biological systematics and speciation. I formerly taught evolution, systematics and entomology at Oregon State University and Middle Tennessee State University. I also have substantial experience in insect collection curation, at the Yale Peabody Museum, Harvard Museum of Comparative Zoology, Cornell University Insect Collection, Milwaukee Public Museum, American Museum of Natural History, U. S. National Museum of Natural History, and Oregon State U.

Are we all cladists?
Chapter
  • Jul 2016
  • Andrew V Z Brower
This chapter argues that cladistics is a coherentist approach to systematics, that Willi Hennig was a coherentist, and that concern with the "true tree" and such metaphysical matters are inconsequential to empirical systematics. The realist approach of model-based methods and the concept of branch length are reviewed.

  • Mar 2014
  • Andrew V Z Brower

Questions

Questions (6)
What are the pros and cons of "sharing preprints of your work"?
Question
  • Dec 2020
The ResearchGate site lists three advantages, but surely there are numerous disadvantages, as well. For example, if you are a systematist publishing nomenclatural acts, the date of "publication" is very important, but that is not the date you post a manuscript to this or another site, such as BioRxiv.
One of the purported advantages is more, earlier citations. But if your preprint is cited, does that "count" as a citation of the published article, or is it something else?
If you post a hot idea as a preprint and somebody else sees it and publishes it first, do you have any recourse to claim that your idea was stolen or plagiarized? Are there established norms in this area?
And from the perspective or readers, perhaps there is an advantage to knowing what colleagues are up to ahead of publication, but to make sure the published version says what you think it does, based on your reading of the preprint, you need to go back and read it again. This seems like a waste of time.
I am curious to know what colleagues think about this practice.
View

Projects (11)
spatial and temporal patterns of diversification in Amazonia
Project
View
monarch butterfly population structure
Archived project
The object of this work was to test the hypothesis that eastern and western North American populations of monarch butterflies are phylogenetically distinct from one another, based on mtDNA. We did not find any evidence to support that. However, this does not mean that the populations are not ecologically distinct, and thus our comments about the dangers of monarch transfer.
View
phylogenetics of skipper butterflies (Hesperiidae)
Project
Work mostly done in collaboration with former student Andy Warren and colleagues. The goal is to generate a stable tree to support the higher-level classification of Hesperiidae.
